title: What will Russian President Vladimir Putin's approval rating be in May 2022, according to the Levada Center?
preds: Putin's popularity will remain resilient for a while longer.
The figure for April was just published, and it is slightly lower than March at 82.

The rating as of March is 83 and given that the Russians consolidate behind nationalistic sentiment, provided that no significant losses are published, I expect that the approval rating will be higher than March also reaching above 90
I believe that Russia will rally behind Putin in the face of international war
Sure, he's a vicious killer and a scrofulous scumbag, but he's just so darn cute!

Russian opposition politician @vkaramurza says “so-called opinion poll numbers” alleging vast support for Putin’s invasion of Ukraine are “meaningless in an authoritarian state where people have no access to objective information” #Velshi https://twitter.com/velshimsnbc/status/1513191636586713091?s=21&t=H-l-JbqjIjRWBcvyRxS3_Q This is not recent news, however, V Kara-Murza was recently arrested, which reinforce his statements.  Putin’s ratings will be sky-high until he is in office, they will drop the day after.
I don't think it will be any higher than 60 but there is room for doubt as the Russians have tight control on all media in and out of the country

NATO and NATO members will progressively take a distance from the Ukrainian government as the true emerges over Kiev's a very dubious conduct of the war,  not able to control ultra-nationalists militias and their crimes. UN will take over in conducting peace talks, in a multilateral climate of collaboration with China and Russia. Putin will be no longer depicted as a war criminal in the West and even many Russians in the opposition will understand he was right is saying Ukraine need de-nazifying
He is already rated at 83% and I don't see that declining very soon.

If the Levada center won’t publish a fantastic rating by May 25, they will be out of business by May 30.  Levada has become another casualty of the country’s 2012 “foreign agents” law, which the Kremlin uses to crack down on organizations that get funding from outside Russia.  Levada has been designated a “foreign agent” in 2016,

Recent Levada Center polling has shown an uptick in support for Putin, likely owing to effective state control of media feeds that the public consumes. Trending around 71 before the invasion, it's now 83% as of end of March. Whether or not this holds as the sanctions continue to settle in is still the wild card. See https://faridaily.substack.com/p/now-were-going-to-fck-them-all-whats?s=r for some interesting thoughts on what elites are thinking regarding how their futures are tied to Putin's future - "...Putin’s dream of a consolidation among the Russian elite has come true. These people understand that their lives are now tied only to Russia, and that that’s where they’ll need to build them..."

Russians will continue to rally behandling their President, nationalistic and misinformed as the are. However, as the information about the young casualties starttid spread and the war may continue to develop in the Rong direction, he may start to find a declining approval rating, I think we are a long way in time for that to happen.

Below is part of an article dated 2018 from The Atlantic. Already back then there was a sense that the much respected Levada Center needed to be careful about its work. Presently I am very skeptical that the data published is reliable, or as the article concludes Levada will be forced to shut down permanently.
▪️▪️▪️
The Levada Center has been operating independently since 2003. But there’s no guarantee it will stay that way.
In 2016, the Russian government designated Levada as a “foreign agent” after it reported an 8 percent drop in the ruling party’s approval ratings. Russia’s “foreign agents” law is largely seen as a way for the Kremlin to crack down on organizations that it finds disagreeable, such as the human rights group, Memorial. The law requires all nonprofits that receive outside funding to register as foreign agents, which bars them from participating in any activity that is perceived to be political or interfering with domestic affairs.
Outside observers consider the Levada Center one of the most reputable sources of polling within Russia. Without it, an accurate sense of public opinion is hard to come by. The center did not release any polling data during Russia’s latest presidential election cycle, citing fears of being forced to shut down permanently.
rally 'round the flag effect will probably have not worn off before may

Because I view the results of the Levada Center with extreme skepticism (incentives to lie in polls, uncertain oversight/review of the results), I think approval rating will increase (because there is no advantage for the rating to decrease and an increase might help with internal propaganda purposes).

Today, the Levada Center published Putin's approval rating for March: 83%! That's a 12-point increase with respect to February. I think the discussion here was divided between observing i) a steep increase in Putin's popularity by uniting the country in the face of the invasion, and ii) a sharp drop due to the economic consequences of the sanctions. Apparently, the former scenario has become dominant. What will happen until May? I tend to think Putin's popularity will increase even more or at least remain about the same, since this happened for at least six months after the invasion of Crimea. Though this is a different context with significantly more international pressure. Next month's data point might be crucial. But I feel pretty confident the answer will lie in between 70% and 90%. Putin's popularity sharpest decrease in the last 10 years was only 6 points a month. And his popularity never surpassed 90%.

Well this readout gapped up more than I thought and is probably going to be sticky for a couple months. It definitely sets a new baseline in my mind. https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/31/world/europe/faced-with-foreign-pressure-russians-rally-around-putin-poll-shows.html
Approval through the roof for March and it stayed that way for years after Crimea
People like the devil they know more than the devil they don't. Most are cut off from facts, so approval rating remains higher than Bidens.

The minimum of all time was 59% in April of 2020. That's also the only time in the entire time series that the value was below 60. The rating also has topped out at 89% and visited the high 80's several times. I don't see >90% having any meaningful likelihood and <50% seems quite irrelevant as well. My intuition is that this question would have to resolve ambiguous as the Levada Center is dissolved before that happens. It's a crime to talk poorly of the war effort, I don't see how reporting net disapproval would be allowed to happen. So working with the range between 50% and 90%, I see getting into the 60s as plausible but unlikely and same with the rating shooting above 80. Between that though I'm indifferent for how this figure will trend and I see the 60-70 and 70-80 buckets as equally likely given the Feb readout of 71%. If the March value moves in either direction I'll shift more probability in that direction. I don't have a lot of faith in my ability to reason ahead about what public sentiment will do in a country that:
1) I don't live in
2) Speaks a language I don't
3) Has state controlled media
4) Is very large Public sentiment and culture are slippery things and I think a lot of humility is in order here.

I think the assumption that it will decrease may be misleading. It may in fact increase. The protesters in Russia may seem like evidence that the Russians as a whole are against the invasion / military operation / war or whatever you want to call it. However, look at what we saw in Canada: the trucker anti-vaccine and anti-restrictions protest and blockade. This was big news in the country and that region near the USA, but these people accounted for a fraction of the total population of Canada and did not reflect the views of the majority. In this case, we may see a rise in polling after the Feb. invasion / military operation / whatever you wanna call it. Just 1% of Russia's population is still 1 and a half million people. Don't assume just because you see a million people protesting "Putin's war" that Russia as a whole will also subscribe to this thinking. I also read a scientific paper's Abstract that found Putin's approval ratings do in fact reflect the honest beliefs of the people surveyed, possibly due to a "healthy" propaganda establishment.
Approval seems to hover in a band between 20 and 80% over the years. So seems unlikely to lie outside of this band.
I personally think his days are numbered. If the cosmonauts can arrive on the space station wearing Ukraine colored overalls then id say people in high positions are making signals!
Adjusted predicted ratings upwards to reflect reassessment of Putin's potential to remain popular or grow in popularity, due to how the war could be perceived within Russia.

If its above 50% I'll chalk it up to manipulation or public pressure. As Russia's economy spirals, it will be less able to provide for the people, and will leave many more willing to voice dissent.  We are already seeing public dissent in ways not normally witnessed coming out of Russia.

We're seeing a bit more traction with anti-war activism, still not at a tipping point but seems to suggest a slightly higher chance of falling approvals as time drags and energy grows in the opposition.  It is not clear to me what happens to this question if VP is no longer President in May- is it void or how would approval be measured?
Putin’s rating won’t change much according to Levada because they are not able to ascertain actual public opinion.

Past wars have been immensely popular and autocrats can engage in heavy amounts of propaganda campaigning. Protesters will continue, but serious economic blowbacks will likely not trigger swings in popularity by so close a date as May.
The latest reading is 70%+ and the state is getting increasingly authoritative. The people maybe afraid to say that they do not approve of Putin even if they feel that way.

Current Levada numbers have shown softness in the Russian's Approval of the Government and Assessment of the Situation in the Country since mid-2019. Despite these sentiments, Putin's approval rating has hovered in the low- to -mid-60's. When Russia invaded Ukraine and annexed Crimea in Feb/Mar 2014, Putin got a significant bump in his approval rating. This has not yet been observed in Feb polling, so it is unclear if the Russian population's sentiment is as positive this time around. Perhaps we'll have to wait till the March polling numbers are out.

The population of Russians over 50 Is consistent with Putin’s approval rating of 60%. As of 2021 Russians over 50 or 57% of the population. The younger population , Because of technology, has been exposed to a much different pool of information. Their demographic is consistent with the disapproval rating of Putin. I don’t see that changing much more than 10 points in a downward direction due to the consumption of state media by people 50 and over. Of course, the younger more informed demographic will have some success influencing the older population. Ie.   https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.businessinsider.com/ukrainians-struggle-to-persuade-russia-relatives-over-putin-propaganda-2022-3%3Famp

The Russian people have more exposure to outside news sources than in countries like China.  There are already protests of the action in Ukraine and as violence increases so will Russian casualties that will be difficult to ignore or propagandize.  Russians may be unlikely to coalesce to overthrow Putin, but his approval ratings from any sources that aren't co-opted by the government are almost certain to fall.

Average around 65% approved 
While on average 34% disapproved

In Feb, Putin has a 71% rating, up from 63% in Nov. It has never been lower than 59%. In 2014 around the time of annexation of Crimea, it shot up from low 60s to high 80s. 10% chance between 40 and 50 because of the chance that sanctions will bite hard and human toll will be intolerance for ordinary Russians.
30% chance between 50 and 60 because: similar to above reasoning, but less extreme outcome.
45% chance between 60 and 70 because: simlar to above, but again less extreme outcome. This also caters for the potential for Putin's popularity growing amongst some Russians if Russia achieves significant gains in the war by May.
15% chance between 70 and 80 because of the chance that Russia will gain some wins in Ukraine by May, bounce back from sanctions (perhaps with China's help) and because of Russia's potential to effectively control the narrative within Russia about the war.

Really tough to predict. If the war is still going AND media remains censored AND the Levada Centre is allowed to operate without additional state influence then his approval will remain solid but not extremely high. All the other dynamics here are largely or completely hidden and add a huge degree of uncertainty.

FSB analyst have a demonstrated that Russia's economy can only last until June of 2022; This has the potential to spiral into world war and higher than normal & fictitious presidential approval ratings as Russia's populous gravitates towards a nationalist view during a possible nuclear war.

Some time before this Q expires, the Levada Center may well be either extinguished or domesticated.   They will certainly not be permitted to report any number lower than 50%, or will censor themselves to avoid doing so.  Vlad the Shirtless is probably not yet ready to demand a number in the 90s, though.   We will all be sad when Levada becomes unreliable, but there is probably no way to save them in the short term.

I changed my prediction. I failed to consider how important it will be for the oligarchs to convince the "people" that Putin is supported (or at least those wealthy enough to fund war or call for war)--- . As the government becomes more "unstable" and wild--- corruption/violence associated with corruption and "keeping the voice" of the people down will increase. In this I suspect Levada will not hear as much contempt nor be as willing/able to speak "truth".
I started quite narrow but saw that in the past after Crimea's annexation, the approval rating went up quite dramatically, so I widen my probability range.

From looking at the 30 year trend, there is a floor of 60 and a ceiling of 90, I'm putting 80% in that range with most of the remaining 20% in below 60 in case public opinion turns on him for the Ukrainian war.
Weird stuff happens when you control the narrative.
